Award.AwardTitle: Efficient Algorithms for Complex Multiphase Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many problems involve multiply-connected moving interfaces, including liquid and solid foams, coarsening in materials, complex mixing in fluids, and evolving cell structures in biology. These problems have multiple domains which share common walls meeting in multiple junctions. Boundaries move under forces which depend on both local and global geometric properties, such as surface tension and volume constraints, as well long-range physical forces, including incompressible flow, membrane permeability, and elastic forces.

This proposal is aimed toward developing, implementing, and applying new numerical methods for propagating multiphase interfaces in a complex physical settings. One of the central computational tools will be the recently developed Voronoi Implicit Interface Methods, which is a mathematical perspective and associated numerical methodology for tracking interfaces in general multiphase problems. These methods offer accurate, consistent, and efficient schemes for multi-dimensional coupled multiphase, which handle complex triple joints/junction, topological change, and naturally couple to complex physics. The investigator and his colleagues will develop new algorithmic tools for multiphase coupled transport problems, and will apply these techniques to computing solid and liquid foams, as well as manufacturing techniques for new materials, providing new methods to compute, refine, and optimize the design and performance cf complex materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have been developing mathematical and numerical methods to study a wide variety of physical phenomena that involve moving interfaces interacting with fluids and materials. These are typically problems in which the boundary between two or more separate regions, called "phases", move in complex ways. Examples include ink/air boundaries in industrial inkjet plotters, evolving air pockets in industrial liquid foams, settling into solid foams, electrically charged paint droplets in industrial painting, the various steps involved in the manufacture of semiconductors, and determining the structural boundaries of complex substances, such as viruses and ceramic component materials imaged under high powered X-ray sources.

These interfaces can twist and turn in complex ways, break into multiple pieces, merge into contorted objects, and both dissappear and nucleate from minute sub-regions. Tracking this intricate motion becomes especially complex in three dimensions.

Much of the progress in this area has resulted from devising new ways to frame the mathematics of moving interfaces, borrowing ideas from various branches of mathematics, including differential geometry, partial differential equations, computational harmonic analysis, and discrete graph networks.

The work supported by NSF over the life of this grant has led to new understanding of multiphase, multiscale interface phenomena, and has opened the door to new simulations of crack/fracture dynamics, industrial mixing, high speed rotary bell painting, injection processes, andinterface dynamics across many industrial applications.
